newsitem.title: SOUTH KOREA: Anti-Japanese protesters rally in Seoul.
newsitem.headline: Anti-Japanese protesters rally in Seoul.

text.p: About 500 South Korean protesters gathered in Seoul on Saturday to demand that Tokyo pay compensation to victims of Japan's World War Two atrocities, witnesses said.
South Koreans have demanded that Japan compensate women, known euphemistically as "comfort women", whom it forced into prostitution during World War Two.
Historians say as many as 200,000 women, many of them Korean, were rounded up and forced to serve as wartime sex slaves for the Japanese Imperial Army.
Japan has maintained that the issue was settled in post-war treaties.
Saturday's rally at a park in central Seoul marked the 78th anniversary of the March 1, 1919 Independence Movement against Japanese colonial rule in Korea.
Japan's 1910-1945 colonisation of the peninsula has left deep scars in the relationship between the two peoples.
The Seoul protesters also waved pickets and banners that read "Stop claiming sovereignty of Tokto" and "Stop distorting history".
The two small Sea of Japan islets known as Tokto in Korea and Takeshima in Japan are at the centre of a territorial dispute that also has inflamed anti-Japanese opinion in South Korea.
Riot police confronted protesters as they tried to march towards the Japanese embassy, but there were no reports of violence.
Several protesters managed to reach the mission, where they hung a large white cloth bearing anti-Japanese slogans on the embassy gate. The cloth was quickly removed by police.
